callForPapers:
# PADL 2025: Call for Papers

The 27th International Symposium on Practical Aspects of Declarative Languages (PADL 2025) will take place on **Mon 20 Jan 2025** and **Tue 21 Jan 2025** at the **Curtis Hotel Denver, Denver, Colorado, United States**.

## Introduction

Declarative languages, including functional, logic, and constraint programming, have sound theoretical bases and attractive frameworks for application development, with successful applications in various real-world situations. PADL is a well-established forum for researchers and practitioners to present original work emphasizing novel applications and implementation techniques for all forms of declarative programming.

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   Innovative applications of declarative languages
*   Declarative domain-specific languages and applications
*   Practical applications of theoretical results
*   New language developments and their impact on applications
*   Declarative languages and software engineering
*   Evaluation of implementation techniques on practical applications
*   Practical experiences and industrial applications
*   Novel uses of declarative languages in the classroom
*   Practical extensions such as constraint-based, probabilistic, and reactive languages

PADL 2025 especially welcomes new ideas and approaches related to applications, design, and implementation of declarative languages going beyond the scope of the past PADL symposia, for example, advanced database languages and contract languages, as well as verification and theorem-proving methods that rely on declarative languages.

## Invited Talks

*   **Solvers, unite! A simple unified semantics for reasoning with assurance and agreement** by Y. Annie Liu (Stony Brook University)
*   **Bridging Safety and Performance** by Umut A. Acar (Carnegie Mellon University)

## Submissions

PADL 2025 welcomes the following submission types:

*   **Regular papers:** (max. 15 pages, excluding references) for original research results on complex/real-world applications, tools/systems, or technical results. These will be published in the formal proceedings.
*   **Short papers:** (max. 8 pages, excluding references) for original research results on complex/real-world applications, tools/systems, or technical results. These will be published in the formal proceedings.
*   **Extended abstracts:** (max. 3 pages) for new ideas, new perspectives, or work-in-progress. These will be posted on the symposium website but not in the formal proceedings.

All page limits exclude references.

### Submission Guidelines

*   Submissions must be written in English and formatted according to the standard **Springer LNCS style**. Guidelines can be found here: [https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines)
*   The review process is **double-anonymous**. Authors must omit names and institutions, refer to their prior work in the third person, and avoid acknowledgments that might identify them.
*   Additional material for reviewers (e.g., proofs) may be placed in a clearly marked appendix, which is not included in the page limit. Reviewers are not obliged to read appendices.
*   Page numbers (and line numbers if possible) should appear on the manuscript. For LaTeX, use:
    ```latex
    \pagestyle{plain}
    \usepackage{lineno}
    \linenumbers 
    ```
*   Papers should be submitted electronically via [EquinOCS](https://equinocs.springernature.com/service/padl2025). Registration is required if you do not have an account.

## Distinguished Papers

The authors of a small number of distinguished papers will be invited to submit a longer, substantially extended version (roughly 30%) for journal publication in **Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP)** or **Journal of Functional Programming (JFP)**.

## Awards

*   **Best Student Paper Award:**
    *   Zachary Hansen, Yuliya Lierler: “SM-based Semantics for Answer Set Programs Containing Conditional Literals and Arithmetic”
*   **Best Student Paper Honorable Mention:**
    *   Kento Takyu, Kazunori Ueda: “Enhancing a Hierarchical Graph Rewriting Language based on MELL Cut Elimination”

## Important Dates (AoE - UTC-12h)

*   **Abstract submission:** Fri 11 Oct 2024
*   **Paper submission:** Fri 18 Oct 2024
*   **Notification to authors:** Thu 14 Nov 2024
*   **Final version:** Sun 24 Nov 2024
*   **Symposium:** Mon 20 Jan - Tue 21 Jan 2025

## Registration for PADL 2025

Registration for PADL 2025 is handled separately from POPL. At least one author of each accepted paper must register for PADL.

*   **Early registration deadline:** December 29, 2024

### Registration Rates (British Pounds)

*   **Student:**
    *   *Early Rate:* **£310**
    *   *Regular Rate:* **£335**
*   **Regular:**
    *   *Early Rate:* **£420**
    *   *Regular Rate:* **£500**

Registration includes venue, lunch, and coffee breaks.

#### Steps for Registering

1.  Wire a bank transfer to the following account:
    *   Bank: Natwest (UK)
    *   Bank address: 36 St Andrew Square, Edinburgh, EH2 2YB
    *   Account name: THE ASSOCIATION FOR LOGIC PROGRAMMING Ltd
    *   Account holders address: Care of Marina De Vos, Dept Computer Science, University of Bath, BA2 7AY
    *   Sort Code: 60-02-05
    *   Account Number: 66462738
    *   BIC: NWBKGB2L
    *   IBAN: GB74NWBK60020566462738
    *   *(Note: Transfer charges are assumed by the payer. Transfers usually take a week.)*
2.  Contact Marina De Vos for payment queries.
3.  Once the transfer is made, send a copy of the receipt along with your first name, last name, affiliation, and country to [gvidal@dsic.upv.es](mailto:gvidal@dsic.upv.es) (Cc: [cssmdv@bath.ac.uk](mailto:cssmdv@bath.ac.uk)).

## Student Grants

PADL 2025 encourages student participation by providing grants to partially cover registration and travel costs. Apply by December 25 using this form: [https://forms.gle/Xr4HfxgNRxUAy7jv9](https://forms.gle/Xr4HfxgNRxUAy7jv9). Preference will be given to students presenting their papers. Students from underrepresented groups are strongly encouraged to apply.

## Venue

PADL 2025 will take place at the **Curtis Hotel Denver, 1405 Curtis Street, 80202 Denver, Colorado, United States**.

## Co-located Events

PADL 2025 is co-hosted with POPL 2025 and is part of the following:

### Co-hosted Conferences

*   [CPP 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/CPP-2025)
*   [VMCAI 2025](https://conf.researchr.org/home/VMCAI-2025)

### Workshops

*   [CoqPL 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/CoqPL-2025)
*   [Dafny 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/dafny-2025)

*   [PEPM 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/pepm-2025)
*   [PLMW @ POPL 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/PLMW-POPL-2025)
*   [PLanQC 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/planqc-2025)
*   [PriSC 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/prisc-2025)
*   [TPSA 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/tpsa-2025)
*   [WAW 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/waw-2025)
*   [WITS 2025](https://popl25.sigplan.org/home/wits-2025)

## Contact

Questions? Use the [PADL contact form](https://popl25.sigplan.org/contact2/PADL-2025-papers).

callForPapers:
# PEPM 2025: Call for Papers

The ACM SIGPLAN Workshop on Partial Evaluation and Program Manipulation (PEPM) has a history going back to 1991 and has been held in conjunction with POPL every year since 2006. PEPM focuses on semantics-based program manipulation, covering automated techniques for evaluating programs with partial input, and broader areas of systematic program generation, analysis, and transformation while maintaining semantic properties.

PEPM 2025 is co-located with POPL 2025 and will be held on **January 21, 2025**, in **Denver, Colorado, United States**.

## Scope

In addition to traditional PEPM topics, PEPM 2025 welcomes submissions in new domains, in particular:

*   Semantics-based and machine-learning-based program synthesis and program optimization.
*   Modeling, analysis, and transformation techniques for distributed and concurrent protocols and programs, such as session types, linear types, and contract specifications.

More generally, topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   **Program and model manipulation techniques:** supercompilation, partial evaluation, fusion, on-the-fly program adaptation, active libraries, program inversion, slicing, symbolic execution, refactoring, decompilation, and obfuscation.
*   **Techniques treating programs/models as data objects:** metaprogramming, generative programming, embedded domain-specific languages (DSLs), program synthesis by sketching and inductive programming, staged computation, and model-driven program generation and transformation.
*   **Program analysis techniques for manipulation:** abstract interpretation, termination checking, binding-time analysis, constraint solving, type systems, automated testing and test case generation.
*   **Applications:** case studies of program manipulation in real-world projects, descriptions of robust tools, DSL implementations, visual languages, end-user programming, scientific computing, middleware, embedded and resource-limited computation, and security.

Questions regarding the scope can be directed to the program co-chairs: Guillaume Allais (guillaume.allais@strath.ac.uk) and Annie Liu (liu@cs.stonybrook.edu).

> **AUTHORS TAKE NOTE:** The official publication date is the date the proceedings are made available in the ACM Digital Library. This date may be up to two weeks prior to the first day of the conference. The official publication date affects the deadline for any patent filings related to published work.

## Submission Types

Three kinds of submissions will be accepted:

1.  **Regular Research Papers:**
    *   Must not exceed **12 pages**.
    *   Judged on originality, correctness, significance, and clarity.
    *   Accepted papers will appear in formal proceedings published by ACM and be included in the ACM Digital Library.
2.  **Short Papers:**
    *   Must not exceed **6 pages**.
    *   May include tool demonstrations and presentations of exciting, even if not fully polished, research or applications.
    *   Accepted short papers do not constitute formal publications and will not appear in the proceedings.
3.  **Talk Proposals:**
    *   Must not exceed **2 pages**.
    *   May propose lectures on topics of interest, existing relevant contributions, or promising work not yet mature enough for papers.

*References and appendices are not included in page limits. Appendices may not necessarily be read by reviewers.*

## Submission Guidelines

*   **Formatting:** Submissions should be typeset using the two-column `sigplan` sub-format of the new `acmart` format. Template available at: [http://sigplan.org/Resources/Author/](http://sigplan.org/Resources/Author/)
*   **Submission System:** Electronically via HotCRP: [https://pepm25.hotcrp.com](https://pepm25.hotcrp.com)
*   **Reviewing:** Single-blind reviewing.
*   **Presentation:** At least one author of each accepted contribution must attend the workshop (physically or virtually) to present the work. A live demonstration is expected for tool demonstration papers.

## Important Dates (AoE - Anywhere on Earth)

*   **Abstract deadline:** Mon 14 Oct 2024
*   **Submission deadline:** Fri 18 Oct 2024
*   **Author notification:** Mon 18 Nov 2024
*   **Camera ready version:** Wed 4 Dec 2024
*   **Workshop Date:** Tue 21 Jan 2025

## Invited Speakers

callForPapers:
# Call for Papers: IFIP International Symposium on Computing Performance, Modelling, Measurement and Evaluation (PERFORMANCE 2025)

The IFIP PERFORMANCE 2025 conference will be held at the Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica (CWI) in Amsterdam on **November 11-14, 2025**.

## Overview

This conference aims to bring together researchers interested in understanding and improving the performance of computing and communication systems through state-of-the-art quantitative models and solution techniques. We invite submissions of research papers focusing on algorithm design, mathematical analysis and modeling, simulation, and measurement techniques for computer systems and communication networks. Contributions that introduce novel performance evaluation methods or creatively apply existing techniques to predict or gain insights into key design trade-offs across a wide range of computing, networked, and cyber-physical systems are particularly welcome.

## Submission Categories

*   **Regular papers:** Up to **20 pages** (single-column format, excluding references).
*   **Short papers:** **5 pages** in the new PER double-column format.

## Important Dates

*   Submission site opens: **May 1, 2025**
*   Abstract submission: **June 8, 2025**
*   Full paper submission: **June 15, 2025**
*   Notification to authors: **July 30, 2025**

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to, the following:

### Performance-oriented methodologies include:

*   Analytical modeling techniques and model validation
*   Anomaly detection, problem diagnosis, and troubleshooting
*   Capacity planning, resource allocation, routing, scheduling, and quality of service
*   Experimental design, statistical analysis, simulation
*   Game theory, network economics, and platform design
*   Machine learning, data mining, graph analysis, optimization
*   Performance, scalability, power, and reliability analysis
*   Stochastic modeling, statistical analysis, and simulation
*   Sustainability analysis and power management
*   Complex networks, sorting, and ranking
*   System measurement, performance monitoring, and forecasting
*   Workload characterization and benchmarking

### Evaluation techniques and algorithms for:

*   Artificial intelligence and machine learning platforms
*   Blockchains and crypto-currency
*   Computer architectures and operating systems
*   Cyber-physical systems, the Internet of Things, and smart grids
*   Data centers, content delivery, cloud computing, and virtualization
*   High-performance computing
*   Internet and web services
*   Mobile and personal computing systems
*   Network architectures, protocols, and congestion control
*   Network economics and platform design
*   Privacy and algorithmic fairness
*   Security systems
*   Storage systems and data centers
*   Social networks, multimedia systems, and smart grid
*   Virtualization, data centers, distributed and cloud computing, fog, and edge computing
*   Quantum computing and quantum communication
*   Wireless, ad-hoc, and cellular networks

## Submission Process

*   Submissions should be made through the [online hotCRP platform](https://performance2025.hotcrp.com/) in printable PDF form.
*   All submissions will be reviewed using a **double-blind review process**. Authors should ensure their paper is anonymized.
*   Authors must declare conflicts with TPC members truthfully on the submission page.
*   Authors of papers previously submitted to Sigmetrics 2023 are required to declare this information during paper registration.

## Format Guidelines

*   **Regular papers:** Should not exceed 20 pages (single-column format) for technical content. Authors are recommended to use the [Elsevier article class elsarticle.cls](https://www.elsevier.com/journals/performance-evaluation/0166-5316/guide-for-authors).
*   **Short papers:** Limited to 5 pages (in the new PER double-column format). Accepted short papers will be published in a special ACM Performance Evaluation Review (PER) issue.
*   Appendices (of unrestricted length) are allowed for supplementary material only and will not be reviewed.

## Special Issues

Accepted regular papers will be published in a special Performance Evaluation (PEVA) issue. Authors may opt-out of publication in PEVA in favor of an expedited review process in journals related to Performance Evaluation and Operations Research, such as:

*   [ACM Transactions on Modeling and Performance Evaluation of Computer Systems (ToMPECS)](https://tompecs.acm.org/)
*   Queueing Systems: Theory and Application (QUESTA)
*   Stochastic Models

## Policies

*   **Soft tracking** is used for submissions.
*   **Anonymity guidelines** must be followed for double-blind reviewing.
*   The list of authors is expected to remain the same from submission to camera-ready.
*   Submissions must present original research. Previous publication of preliminary work as an extended abstract at a workshop is acceptable if it includes substantial new material.
*   Simultaneous submissions are not allowed.
*   Papers accompanied by nondisclosure agreement forms will not be considered.

## Ethical Considerations

Papers describing experiments with users or user data should follow basic principles of ethical research. Authors are encouraged to include a subsection describing these issues. Authors must attest that their work complies with all applicable ethical standards of their home institution(s).

## Diversity & Inclusiveness

Guidelines are provided to promote inclusiveness and accessibility in paper submissions and conference presentations.

callForPapers:
# PKC 2025: Call for Papers

PKC 2025 will take place in **Røros, Norway** from **May 12-15, 2025**. The conference is organized by the **International Association for Cryptologic Research (IACR)** and **NTNU**.

## General Information

Original research papers on all aspects of public-key cryptography, covering theory, implementations and applications, and related fields, are solicited for submission to PKC 2025, the International Conference on Practice and Theory in Public Key Cryptography.

Areas of interest include research on:

*   Public key schemes, such as their design and analysis (including side channel attacks), from its math to actual systems.
*   The design, proposal, and analysis of cryptographic primitives and protocols.
*   Public-key techniques in MPC or other protocols.

Purely information-theoretic and symmetric-key subjects, e.g., block cipher design and attacks, are not in scope.

This year, we particularly welcome submissions on the theme of **“Real-world public-key cryptography.”** These submissions must still meet the acceptance criteria for PKC.

## Submission Guidelines

Author instructions for paper submission may be found on the submission page: [Submit a paper](papersubmission.php)

## Important Dates

*   **Submission deadline:** Oct 16, 2024 (11:59pm AoE)
*   **First round notification:** Dec 11, 2024
*   **Rebuttal deadline:** Dec 18, 2024
*   **Final notification:** Feb 5, 2025
*   **Final versions due:** Feb 26, 2025
*   **Conference begins:** May 12, 2025

## Schedule

PKC 2025 will operate a two-round review system with a rebuttal phase. In the first round, the program committee selects submissions for the second round, and authors receive notification with review comments. Authors of selected submissions can submit a rebuttal letter. Submissions not selected in the first round may be submitted to other conferences after the first round notification.

## Awards

The Program Committee may choose a paper for an overall best paper award. Additionally, to promote early-career researchers, a prize for the best paper authored exclusively by early-career researchers may be awarded. To be eligible, all co-authors must be full/part-time students or have received their degree in 2019 or later. Awards will only be given if deserving papers are identified.

## Stipends

Students whose papers are accepted and who present their talks at the conference will have their registration waived. A limited number of stipends are available for those unable to obtain funding to attend. Students presenting their own accepted papers are encouraged to apply if assistance is needed. Requests for stipends should be sent to the general chair.

The event will take place from July 21-24, 2025, in Las Vegas, USA. PDPTA serves researchers, scholars, professionals, and academicians, and is held jointly with 20 other conferences within CSCE'25. Accepted papers will be published by Springer Nature and indexed in major Science Citation Indexation databases.
callForPapers:
# PDPTA'25: Call for Papers

The 31st International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Processing Techniques and Applications (PDPTA'25) is being held jointly with The 2025 World Congress in Computer Science, Computer Engineering, and Applied Computing (CSCE'25).

### Conference Details

*   **Dates:** July 21-24, 2025
*   **Location:** Las Vegas, USA
*   **Participation:** In-person attendance is expected, with online presentation options available.

PDPTA'25 aims to provide a platform for researchers, scholars, professionals, students, and academicians to share novel ideas and research results in the application of human cognition models in various practical computing applications.

## Publication

All accepted papers will be published by **Springer Nature** (https://www.springernature.com/) in the proceedings (Research Books) and indexed in major Science Citation Indexation databases, including Scopus, DBLP, EI Engineering Index, Web of Science, and others.

## Topics of Interest

Topics include, but are not limited to:

*   **Big Data and High-Performance Computing:** Novel computational methodologies, HPC and scalable algorithms for enhancing data quality, models and frameworks for Big Data, graph algorithms, computational science, computational intelligence, Scalable systems and architectures for Big Data, etc.
*   **Parallel/Distributed Applications:** Numerical computations/methods, neural networks and fuzzy logic, medicine, remote sensing, computer vision, computer graphics and virtual reality, parallel/distributed databases, banking, financial markets, high-performance computational biology, etc.
*   **Parallel/Distributed Architectures:** Clusters and parallel systems of various topologies, supercomputers, shared memory, distributed memory, general- and special-purpose architectures, instructional level parallelism, etc.
*   **Networks and Interconnection Networks:** Scalable networks, reconfigurable networks, routing issues, general-purpose network performance for distributed applications, network protocols, internet technology, optical interconnections and computing, novel network topologies, etc.
*   **Energy/power-aware Computing:** Energy-aware resource management, green computing, energy efficiency planning, energy-aware technologies, low power virtualization and software techniques, low power logic/circuit/process technology design, methods and tools for forecasting, estimating, and validating power use, etc.
*   **Reliability and Fault-tolerance:** Software and hardware fault-tolerance (system- and application-level), fault diagnosis, fault-tolerance measurement.
*   **Building Block Processors:** Applications of processors that can be used as basic building blocks for multicomputer systems.
*   **Real-time and Embedded Systems:** Small-scale parallel systems for high-performance control, data acquisition, and analysis; configuration, routing, scheduling, performance guarantees, etc.
*   **Parallel/Distributed Algorithms:** Algorithms exploiting clusters and general-purpose distributed and parallel systems, new vector/pipeline issues, shared memory, distributed memory, virtual memory, etc.
*   **Multimedia Communications, Systems, and Applications:** High-speed networking, multimedia architectures and protocols, multimedia applications, quality of service support, operating system and networking support, internet tools and applications, audio/video delivery over the internet, etc.
*   **Software Tools and Environments for Parallel and Distributed Platforms:** Operating systems, compilers, languages, debuggers, monitoring tools, software engineering on parallel/distributed systems, etc.
*   **High-performance Computing in Computational Science:** Intra-disciplinary and multi-disciplinary research programs and applications.
*   **Performance Evaluation and Management of Wireless Networks and Distributed Systems.**
*   **FPGA-based Design.**
*   **Performance Analysis, Evaluation, Prediction, ...**
*   **Nanotechnology in HPC.**
*   **High-performance Mobile Computation and Communication.**
*   **Object Oriented Technology and Related Issues.**
*   **Scheduling and Resource Management.**
*   **Petri Nets: Theory, Analysis, Tools and Applications.**
*   **Web-based Simulation and Computing.**
*   **Cloud Computing.**
*   **Complex Systems, Theory and Applications.**
*   **Other Aspects and Applications relating to High-Performance Computations.**
*   **Emerging Technologies.**

## Submission Instructions

*   **Submission Website:** https://american-cse.org/cgi-bin/submit/index.cgi?xprint_submit
*   **Paper Formats:** PDF or MS WORD.
*   **Formatting:** For draft submissions, all reasonable formatting is acceptable. Authors of accepted papers will receive specific typesetting instructions for the final version, which should use the standard Springer Nature typesetting format (guidelines available at: https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines).
*   **Content of First Page:** Title, Author(s) name(s), affiliation(s), City, Country, email address (identify Contact Author), Abstract (100-120 words), max 6 topical keywords, and submission type (e.g., "Regular Research Paper", "Short Research Paper", or "Extended Abstract/Poster Research Paper").
*   **Originality:** Submissions must be original and not under consideration elsewhere.
*   **Paper Categories and Page Limitations:** Refer to https://american-cse.org/csce2025/paper_categories

## Important Dates

*   **Submission Due Date:** Refer to https://american-cse.org/csce2025/deadlines

## Contact

*   **Email:** cs@american-cse.org

callForPapers:
# IEEE PIMRC 2025: Call for Papers

The 36th edition of the IEEE International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC) will be held in **Istanbul, Türkiye**, from **September 1–4, 2025**.

PIMRC is one of the major conferences of the IEEE Communications Society (ComSoc), attracting technical communities globally and focusing on wireless communications and networking.

Prospective authors are invited to submit original technical papers, as well as proposals for special sessions and workshops. The conference welcomes contributions reporting original research results in all areas of wireless technology, as well as in applications, services, and business.

## Submission Types

*   **Technical Papers:** Original technical contributions.
*   **Proposals for Special Sessions:** [See Special Session Guidelines](/authors/special-session-guidelines)
*   **Proposals for Workshops:** [See Call for Workshop Proposals](/authors/call-workshop-proposals)
*   **Workshop Papers:** [See Call for Workshop Papers](/authors/call-workshop-papers)
*   **Panel Proposals:** [See Call For Panels](/authors/call-panels)
*   **Tutorial Proposals:** [See Call for Tutorial Proposals](/authors/call-tutorial-proposals)

## Topics of Interest

Submissions are invited in the following tracks:

### Track 1: Fundamentals and PHY

*   AI and ML in/for communications
*   Coding/modulation, information theory
*   Channel modeling and equalization
*   Cooperative communications, coded caching/computing
*   Integrated sensing and communications
*   Millimeter wave and Terahertz communications
*   Multi-user communications and interference mitigation
*   Optical wireless and visible light communications
*   Physical layer security
*   Propagation, antennas and beamforming
*   Quantum communications
*   Semantic communications and signal processing
*   Source coding and joint source-channel coding
*   Synchronization techniques
*   Ultra-wideband communications
*   Ultra/Tera multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO)
*   Wireless information and power transfer

### Track 2: MAC and Cross Layer Design

*   Adaptive and reconfigurable MAC
*   Age of information aware MAC design
*   Information-theoretic approaches to MAC design
*   Joint access and backhaul scheduler design
*   Joint MAC and networking layer design
*   MAC for low-power embedded networks
*   MAC for mobile and vehicular networks
*   ML for resource management
*   Next-generation multiple access
*   Radio resource management, allocation, and scheduling
*   Scheduler for cooperative and relay systems
*   Security issues in MAC design

### Track 3: Mobile and Wireless Networks

*   Ad hoc networks and wireless sensor networks
*   Cognitive radio networks and self-organizing networks
*   Cooperative networking
*   Data-driven, large-scale network modelling and optimization
*   Digital twins and autonomous networks
*   Green and energy-efficient networks
*   Massive Internet of Things (IoT) and sensor networks
*   ML for networking, distributed ML, multi-agent systems
*   Mobile edge, cloud, and fog computing
*   Network security
*   O-RAN
*   Software-defined and open interface-based networks
*   Stochastic geometry
*   UAVs and non-terrestrial networks

### Track 4: Emerging Technologies, Applications and Platforms

*   5G NR and 6G standardization
*   802.11 and next-generation Wi-Fi
*   Connected vehicles and digital twin
*   Experiments, prototypes, and testbeds
*   Fluid antenna communications
*   Full-duplex communication networks
*   Holographic MIMO
*   Innovative implanted and wearable devices
*   Intelligent beamforming relays
*   Joint radar and communications
*   Networking support for virtual and augmented reality
*   Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces
*   Sensing and localization
*   Software defined radio and networks
*   Surface wave communications

## Important Dates

*   **Workshop Proposals:** [Changed or passed: 16 February 2025]
*   **Tutorial Proposals:** [Changed or passed: 16 March 2025]
*   **Paper Submissions:** [Changed or passed: 13 April 2025 (FINAL)]
*   **Panel Proposals:** [Changed or passed: 15 May 2025]
*   **Acceptance Notification:** 5 June 2025 (EXTENDED)
*   **Final Manuscript:** 07 July 2025

## Submission and Author Information

*   **Final Submission Camera Ready Guidelines:** [Link](/authors/final-submission-camera-ready-guidelines)
*   **Download Call for Papers:** [Link](https://pimrc2025.ieee-pimrc.org/sites/pimrc2025.ieee-pimrc.org/files/PIMRC%202025%20-%20Call%20for%20Papers%20-%20March%2031%20version.pdf)

## Registration and Grants

callForPapers:
# PLoP 2025: Call for Submissions

The 32nd Pattern Languages of Programs (PLoP) conference will be held from **October 12-15, 2025**, at **Skamania Lodge, Columbia River Gorge, Washington USA**.

PLoP is the premier event for pattern authors and enthusiasts to gather, discuss, and learn more about patterns, design, software development, and the built world in general. The conference welcomes both paper authors and nonauthors alike.

## Submission Types

There are two main types of submissions:

### PAPERS

*   **DUE:** **June 9** (Extended)
*   **Description:** We welcome papers describing patterns and pattern languages, experience reports, essays, empirical evaluations, reflections, etc. After an initial screening, papers are assigned a shepherd for an iterative revision process. Accepted papers are discussed in Writers’ Workshops at the conference. Authors are expected to improve their papers based on feedback from the workshop and submit a final version for the proceedings.
*   **Contact for Paper Submissions:** Hugo Ferreira (`ploppapers@hillside.net`)
*   **Submission Link:** [https://submission.plopcon.org/plop/2025/submission/gate.cgi](https://submission.plopcon.org/plop/2025/submission/gate.cgi)

### IMAGINATION RUN WILD

*   **DUE:** **July 15**
*   **Description:** These sessions offer everyone, including newcomers, an opportunity to learn about patterns and related topics. Proposals can include hour-long presentations, 5-minute lightning talks, workshops/focus groups, open spaces, fishbowls, or birds-of-a-feather sessions. Propose something new if it doesn't fit the standard formats by contacting Kiyoka Hayashi. Reports from these sessions may be included in the conference proceedings (subject to review).
*   **Contact for Imagination Run Wild:** Kiyoka Hayashi (`plopirw@hillside.net`)
*   **Submission Link:** [https://submission.plopcon.org/plop/2025/submission/gate.cgi](https://submission.plopcon.org/plop/2025/submission/gate.cgi)

## Important Dates (All times AoE - Anytime on Earth)

*   **June 9:** DUE: Paper submissions (Extended!)
*   **June 15:** Notification of acceptance for shepherding. Paper authors will be notified.
*   **July 15:** DUE: Updated papers
*   **July 15:** DUE: Imagination Run Wild submissions
*   **July 30:** Notification of acceptance sent for all submissions
*   **August 10:** Early registration ends (registration fee increases on August 11 and lodging is subject to availability)
*   **August 10:** DUE: All paper authors and Imagination Run Wild facilitators must register by this date.
*   **September 23:** DUE: Conference version of paper
*   **January 15, 2026:** DUE: Proceedings version of paper and Imagination Run Wild reports

## Paper Submission & Review Process

1.  **Initial Screening:** Submissions are assessed for suitability and quality by the program committee.
2.  **Shepherding:** Each suitable paper is assigned a shepherd to help the author improve the paper through an iterative revision process.
3.  **Final Assessment:** After shepherding, papers are re-assessed by program committee members and chairs. Acceptance considers the author's willingness to incorporate feedback.
4.  **Writers’ Workshops:** At the conference, accepted papers are discussed in groups. Authors take comments into account for final improvements.
5.  **Registration Requirement:** At least one author of an accepted paper must register for the conference; failure to do so will result in acceptance being withdrawn.

## Costs

The Hillside organization is a non-profit and does not provide funding for PLoP travel, registration, or lodging. All attendees are responsible for these costs.

callForPapers:
# IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy (SP) 2026: Call for Papers

The 47th IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy (SP 2026) will be held from **May 18-21, 2026**, at the **Hilton San Francisco Union Square, San Francisco, CA**.

## About the Symposium

Since 1980, the IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy has been the premier forum for presenting developments in computer security and electronic privacy, and for bringing together researchers and practitioners in the field. The 2026 Symposium will mark the 47th annual meeting of this flagship conference.

The Symposium will be held on **May 18-20, 2026**, and the Security and Privacy Workshops will be held on **May 21, 2026**.

## Call for Papers

We solicit previously unpublished papers offering novel research contributions in any aspect of security or privacy. Papers may present advances in the theory, design, implementation, analysis, verification, or empirical evaluation and measurement of secure systems. Theoretical papers must make a convincing case for the relevance of their results to practice.

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   Applied cryptography
*   Attacks with novel insights, techniques, or results
*   Authentication, access control, and authorization
*   Blockchains and distributed ledger security
*   Cloud computing security
*   Cyber physical systems security
*   Distributed systems security
*   Economics of security and privacy
*   Embedded systems security
*   Formal methods and verification
*   Hardware security
*   Hate, Harassment, and Online Abuse
*   Human-centered security and privacy
*   Intrusion detection and prevention
*   Malware and unwanted software
*   Network security and measurement
*   ML - Methods for confidentiality and privacy of data in ML systems
*   ML - Methods for integrity and availability of ML systems
*   ML - Novel attacks on ML systems
*   ML - Verifying security and privacy properties of ML algorithms
*   Operating systems security
*   Privacy-enhancing technologies, anonymity, and censorship
*   Program and binary analysis
*   Protocol security
*   Security and privacy metrics
*   Security and privacy policies
*   Security architectures
*   Security for at-risk populations
*   Software supply chain security
*   Systems security
*   User studies for security and privacy
*   Web security and privacy
*   Wireless and mobile security/privacy

Papers without a clear application to security or privacy will be considered out of scope and may be rejected without full review.

## Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) Papers

We solicit SoK papers that evaluate, systematize, and contextualize existing knowledge. These papers can provide an important new viewpoint on an established research area, support or challenge long-held beliefs with compelling evidence, or present a convincing, comprehensive new taxonomy. Papers will be distinguished by the prefix "SoK:" in the title and a checkbox on the submission form. They will be reviewed to the same standards as traditional research papers.

## Submission Deadlines & Decisions

*   **First deadline:**
    *   Abstract registration deadline: **May 29, 2025** (mandatory)
    *   Paper submission deadline: **June 5, 2025**
    *   Early-reject notification: **July 21, 2025**
    *   Rebuttal period (interactive): **August 18 - August 29, 2025**
    *   Rebuttal text due: **August 25, 2025**
    *   Acceptance notification: **September 9, 2025**
    *   Camera-ready deadline: **October 17, 2025**
*   **Second deadline:**
    *   Abstract registration deadline: **November 6, 2025** (mandatory)
    *   Paper submission deadline: **November 13, 2025**
    *   Early-reject notification: **January 19, 2026**
    *   Rebuttal period (interactive): **February 16 - February 27, 2026**
    *   Rebuttal text due: **February 23, 2026**
    *   Acceptance notification: **March 19, 2026**
    *   Camera-ready deadline: **April 17, 2026**

## Rebuttal Period

Papers reaching the second round of reviewing will have an opportunity to write a rebuttal to reviewer questions. This period will be interactive, enabling communication between authors and reviewers via HotCRP’s anonymous communication feature.

## Symposium Event Changes

Due to venue limitations and costs, each accepted paper will have:
*   A short talk presentation (e.g., 5-7 minutes).
*   A poster presentation immediately following the talk session.
All accepted papers are required to present both a short talk and a poster.

## Instructions for Paper Submission

*   Submissions must be original work, with any overlap with previously published or simultaneously submitted papers clearly documented.
*   Simultaneous submission of the same paper to another venue with proceedings or a journal is not allowed.
*   Any author may not submit more than 6 papers per cycle.

## Anonymous Submission

*   Papers must be submitted in a form suitable for anonymous review. No author names or affiliations should appear on the title page, and authors should avoid revealing their identity in the text.
*   Avoid references to your university or institution by name, use generalities like "our university".
*   Do not include acknowledgments that help identify authors.
*   Refer to previous work in the third person, without identifying yourselves. If a third-person reference is infeasible, blind the reference itself.
*   Artifacts repositories should not identify authors.
*   Papers that are not properly anonymized may be rejected without review.

## Conflicts of Interest

Authors must identify any potential conflicts of interest with PC members during submission. Conflicts include co-authorship, working in the same company/university within the past two years, collaboration within the past two years, being a thesis advisor/advisee, or close personal friendship.

## Research Ethics Committee (REC)

Papers flagged by reviewers for potentially ethically fraught research will be reviewed by the REC. The REC may suggest rejection on ethical grounds.

## Ethical Considerations for Vulnerability Disclosure

Where research identifies a vulnerability, authors are expected to act in a way that avoids gratuitous harm. Disclosure to vendors is encouraged, with a typical disclosure window of 45 to 90 days ahead of publication.

Submitted papers must discuss steps taken to address vulnerabilities. CVE identifiers should not be included in the submitted paper to preserve anonymity.

## Ethical Considerations for Human Subjects Research

Submissions involving human subjects must disclose IRB approval/waiver status and discuss steps taken to ensure ethical treatment of participants.

## Financial and Non-financial Competing Interests

Authors must declare any competing financial and/or non-financial interests in the camera-ready versions of their papers.

## Page Limit and Formatting

*   Submitted papers may include up to **13 pages of text** and up to **5 pages for references and appendices** (totaling no more than 18 pages).
*   All text and figures past page 13 must be clearly marked as part of the appendix.
*   Papers must be formatted for US letter size paper.
*   Submissions must use the IEEE “compsoc” conference proceedings template. LaTeX submissions must use `IEEEtran.cls` version 1.8b with options “conference,compsoc.”.
*   Papers that fail to use the correct template, modify margins, font, or line spacing, or use egregious space scrunching are subject to rejection without review.

## Withdrawing Policy

A paper can be withdrawn at any point before reviews are sent to authors. After reviews are sent, withdrawal is not permitted.

## Authorship Policy

Changes to the authorship list are not permitted during submission. Post-acceptance changes require TPC Chair approval.

## ORCID Requirement

All authors are required to submit an ORCID number at paper submission time. Papers without ORCID numbers for all authors will be desk rejected.

## Conference Submission Server

Submissions must be in Portable Document Format (.pdf).

*   First deadline submissions: [https://cycle1.sp2026.ieee-security.org/](https://cycle1.sp2026.ieee-security.org/)

## Publication and Presentation

One of the authors of an accepted paper is expected to register and present the paper at the conference.

## Program Committee

**PC Chairs:**
*   Cristina Nita-Rotaru (Northeastern University)
*   Nicolas Papernot (University of Toronto and Vector Institute and Google DeepMind)

*(A full list of Associate Chairs and PC Members is available on the conference website.)*

callForPapers:
# Call for Papers

## Overview
SoCS 2025 brings researchers in heuristic search and combinatorial search and optimization together to exchange ideas and cross-fertilize the field. Submissions presenting real-world applications of heuristic search are especially invited. The conference is co-located with CP 2025 and SAT 2025, and we particularly welcome papers that explore the intersections between our research topics and the problems studied by these communities.

All accepted papers will be included in the proceedings published by AAAI Press.

**Note:** Submissions are now closed.

## Topics of Interest
Topics of interest include but are not limited to the following:
* Adversarial search
* Analysis of search algorithms
* Automated synthesis of lower bounds
* Bidirectional search
* Bounding and pruning techniques
* Combinatorial optimization
* Combinatorial puzzles
* Continuous problem solving
* Constraint search
* Deep learning in heuristics and search
* External-memory and parallel search
* Heuristics
* Incremental and active learning in search
* Machine learning for or in search algorithms
* Metareasoning and search
* Methodology and critiques of current practice
* Model-based search
* Multi-agent pathfinding
* Pathfinding
* Portfolios of search algorithms
* Problem compilation
* Problem solving using search
* Random vs. systematic search strategy selection
* Real-life applications
* Real-time search
* Reinforcement learning and search
* Search in goal-directed problem solving
* Search space discretization for continuous state-space problems
* Search-based diagnosis
* Search in boolean satisfiability
* Search in machine learning and big data analytics
* Search methods in robotics
* Self-configuring and self-tuning algorithms
* Symmetry handling
* Time, memory, and solution quality trade-offs

## Types of Submissions

We encourage researchers to submit three categories of papers:

1.  **Technical papers**:
    *   Original long (up to 8 pages plus up to one page of references) and short (up to 4 pages plus up to one page of references) papers reporting substantial original research.
    *   Must be original and not submitted concurrently to a journal or another conference.
    *   **Double-blind reviewing**: Papers must omit author names and affiliations.

2.  **Position papers**:
    *   Original long (up to 8 pages plus up to one page of references) and short (up to 4 pages plus up to one page of references) papers discussing ideas and concepts related to heuristic and combinatorial search.
    *   Examples: critiques, bold new perspectives, historical analyses, implementation discussions, methodological contributions, insightful reports on new applications.
    *   **Double-blind reviewing**: Papers must omit author names and affiliations.

3.  **Extended abstracts**:
    *   Up to 2 pages (including references).
    *   For original work, work-in-progress, or work recently appeared or under review at other venues (e.g., AAAI/ICAPS/IJCAI).
    *   Light review to ensure interest to the SoCS community.
    *   **Anonymity**:
        *   New work: Omit author names and affiliations.
        *   Previously published/under-review work: Mention publication/review status on the first page (e.g., "under review for AAAI-2024"). Author information can be included in this specific case.

## Submission Instructions

*   The paper submission is a two-step process:
    1.  Register the paper abstract in EasyChair by the Abstract submission deadline.
    2.  Submit the full paper in PDF by the Paper submission deadline.
*   Supplementary material (video, appendices) is allowed but must also be anonymized. Reviewers are not required to consult it.
*   Technical and position papers must be original and not submitted concurrently elsewhere.
*   Authors will be required to confirm that their submissions conform to these requirements.

## Important Dates

All deadlines are at 23:59 UTC-12.

*   **Paper abstract submission deadline:** March 19, 2025 *(Closed)*
*   **Paper submission deadline:** March 26, 2025 *(Closed)*
*   **Author response:** May 2-5, 2025 *(Past)*
*   **Notification:** May 16, 2025
*   **Camera-ready copy:** May 30, 2025

## Awards

*   **Best paper award:** Technical papers will be considered.
*   **Best student paper award:** Papers where main authors are students at the time of submission will be considered.

## Links

*   [Author kit](https://aaai.org/authorkit25/)
*   [Submission link](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=socs2025)
*   [Important dates](https://socs25.search-conference.org/important-dates)

callForPapers:
# SPM 2025: Call for Papers

The Symposium on Solid and Physical Modeling (SPM) 2025 will take place from **October 29 to November 2, 2025**, in **Hangzhou, Zhejiang, P.R. China**. The conference is co-located with Shape Modeling International (SMI 2025).

## Scope

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   3D fabrication/printing/manufacturing technologies
*   Anisotropic/heterogeneous/composite materials
*   Applied algebraic and differential geometry
*   Applied computational geometry and topology
*   Conceptual, collaborative, and distributed design
*   Computational fabrication
*   Curve, surface, and manifold modeling
*   Dimensioning and tolerancing
*   Feature modeling, recognition, and understanding
*   Geometric algorithms
*   Geometric and topological representations
*   Geometric constraint solving and parametric modeling
*   Geometric interpolation and smoothing
*   Geometry generation and processing
*   Geometry compression and transmission
*   Isogeometric analysis
*   Meshing and mesh optimization
*   Multi-resolution modeling
*   Numerical analysis of geometric algorithms
*   Physically-based modeling and simulation
*   Product data exchange, standards, and interoperability
*   Reverse engineering/reconstruction of surfaces/solids
*   Robustness and validity of geometric computations
*   Shape modeling, synthesis and analysis

## Paper Submissions

*   Accepted full-length papers will be published in the journal of **Computer-Aided Design (Elsevier)** after a rigorous two-stage double-blind review process.
*   Papers should not exceed **12 pages**, including figures and references.
*   It is strongly recommended to use the [LaTeX template](https://spmconf.github.io/SPM2024/SPM2024_Template.zip) for formatting. Papers formatted by MS Word according to the style guidelines for Computer-Aided Design (Elsevier) are also accepted.
*   Submissions must be in PDF format.
*   Submit via the [EasyChair website](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=spm20250).

## Important Dates

*   **Abstract Deadline:** March 8, 2025
*   **Full Paper Deadline:** March 15, 2025
*   **First Review Notification:** April 25, 2025
*   **Revised Papers Due:** May 30, 2025
*   **Final Notification:** August 10, 2025
*   **Camera Ready Papers:** July 30, 2025
*   **Conference:** October 29 – November 02, 2025

## Committees

### Program Committee

*   Yunbo Zhang (Rochester Institute of Technology, USA)
*   Xiaohu Guo (The University of Texas at Dallas, USA)
*   Lucia Romani (Università di Bologna, Italy)

### Organizing Committee

*   Weiwei Xu (Zhejiang University, China)
*   Gang Xu (Hangzhou Dianzi University, China)

## Contact

For questions about submissions, please email: Yunbo Zhang (ywzeie@rit.edu), Xiaohu Guo (xguo@utdallas.edu), and Lucia Romani (lucia.romani@unibo.it).

callForPapers:
# SQM 2026: Call for Papers

The **27th Annual Call Center Industry QA & CX Conference and Awards Ceremony** will be held from **April 29–30, 2026**, at the **Fairmont Le Château Frontenac (5-Star Hotel) in Quebec City, Canada**.

## Why Attend?

Experience a two-day immersion into:

*   Cutting-edge QA and CX research
*   Industry best practices from top-performing organizations
*   Executive and Management/Supervisor learning tracks (invite-only for executives)
*   Invaluable networking with industry leaders and peers
*   Actionable insights to enhance customer satisfaction, compliance, and employee engagement

## Who Should Attend?

*   Customer Experience Officers
*   Call center vice presidents, directors, and managers
*   Managers responsible for quality assurance
*   Staff managers who have responsibilities for improving CX
*   CX research, CX, and QA managers
*   Call center quality assurance leaders
*   World-Class Certified frontline supervisors and agents

## Conference Topics (Tentative)

*   Using Automated QA to Monitor, Motivate, and Manage Agent Performance
*   Agent Engagement Strategies for Remote Work Environments
*   Leveraging AI and Regression Analysis to Predict CSAT
*   Benchmarking with [mySQM™ QA Score](https://www.sqmgroup.com/software)
*   Real-Time Recognition to Drive CX Excellence
*   Empowering Agents with AI-Generated Self-Coaching
*   Improving Agent Soft Skills: Empathy, Friendliness, and Resolution
*   Enhancing Retention and Engagement through AI and Analytics
*   Automating QA for Call Compliance Excellence
*   Promoting Cross-Department Collaboration and Supervisor Coaching
*   Training Agents to Resolve Complex or Challenging Calls
*   Customer Analytics to Improve First Call Resolution (FCR) and CX
*   Behind the Scenes: What it Took to Become the 2025 Call Center of the Year
*   What Drove Success for the 2025 Best Performing Small Call Center

## Registration Pricing (2026)

*   **Executive Track** (Invitation Only): **$3,500**
*   **Executive Track + CX Celebration Day** (Invitation Only): **$4,000**
*   **Supervisor/Management Track**: **$2,400**
*   **Supervisor/Management Track + CX Celebration Day**: **$2,900**
*   **CX Celebration Day** (Open to all roles): **$1,200**
*   **Awards Gala Night Only**: **$400**

*All tracks include access to the Awards Gala Night.*

## Special Offers & Group Discounts

*   10% Group Discount for 4+ Executive/Supervisor Track attendees
*   10% Group Discount for 10+ total conference attendees
*   **Guest Rate:** Bring a special guest (non-employee) for just **$200**—includes all meals, drinks, Lumber Jack / Sugar Shack Party, and Awards Gala Night.
*   **All-Inclusive Guest Package:** Add Appreciation Day activities for a total of **$400**

*Guests may be added after online registration is completed.*

## Registration Status

Registration is not yet available. Dates will be announced when they become available.

callForPapers:
# SPIRE 2025: Call for Papers

The 32nd International Symposium on String Processing and Information Retrieval (SPIRE 2025) will be held from **September 08 - 11, 2025, in London, UK**.

## Scope

SPIRE 2025 covers research in all aspects of string processing, information retrieval, computational biology, and related applications. Typical topics of interest include (but are not limited to):

*   **String Processing:** string pattern matching, text indexing, data structures for string processing, text compression, compressed data structures, compressed string processing, text mining, 2D pattern matching, automata based string processing, combinatorics on words.
*   **Computational Biology:** algorithms for DNA sequencing, assembly, alignments, read error correction, metagenomics, transcriptomics, gene and regulatory element recognition, motif finding, pangenomics, variants discovery, phylogenetics, genome rearrangements.
*   **Information Retrieval:** Retrieval models and ranking. Theoretical models and foundations of IR. Efficiency and scalability topics in IR. Knowledge acquisition in IR. Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing for IR. Knowledge representation and reasoning for IR. User-centric aspects of IR. IR Evaluation. Fairness, accountability, transparency in IR. Domain-specific IR applications. Web search.

## Submissions

SPIRE 2025 invites submissions in two categories:

*   **Long papers:** Up to 12 pages, excluding references and optional appendices.
*   **Short papers:** Up to 6 pages, excluding references and optional appendices.

Papers should be submitted electronically via EasyChair via the following link: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=spire2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=spire2025)

### Publication

As in past editions, the proceedings of SPIRE 2025 will be published by **Springer in the Lecture Notes in Computer Science (LNCS) series**. The use of LNCS templates is mandatory. Suitable templates are available at the Springer Website and on Overleaf. Do not change the margin size or the font, do not make a separate title page, etc.: use the LNCS style file as given.

### Important Notes

*   Simultaneous submissions to other conferences with published proceedings is not permitted.
*   At least one author per accepted paper is expected to register for the conference and present the paper.
*   The conference will be in-person, with online presentations only in special cases (e.g., authors with travel difficulties).

## Important Dates

*   **Papers deadline:**
    *   May 29, 2025 AoE (abstract deadline)
    *   June 5 2025 AoE (firm deadline)
*   **Notifications:** July 17, 2025
*   **Camera-ready due:** TBC
*   **Early bird registration:** TBC

## Events

*   **SPIRE:** September 08 to 10, 2025
*   **Workshop on Compression, Text, and Algorithms (WCTA):** September 11, 2025

## Invited Speakers

*   Hideo Bannai, Institute of Science Tokyo, Japan
*   Camille Marchet, CNRS, Lille, France
*   Rajeev Raman, University of Leicester, UK

## General Chairs

*   Golnaz Badkobeh, City St George’s, University of London, UK
*   Ricardo Baeza-Yates, Barcelona Supercomputing Center, Barcelona, Spain

## Program Committee Chairs

*   Golnaz Badkobeh, City St George’s, University of London, UK
*   Jakub Radoszewski, University of Warsaw, Poland
*   Nicola Tonellotto, University of Pisa, Italy

SYSTOR serves as an international forum for systems research, featuring peer-reviewed research papers, keynote speakers, and a poster session, appealing to both academic and industrial professionals.
callForPapers:
# SYSTOR 2025: Call for Papers

The ACM International Systems and Storage Conference (SYSTOR) is an international forum for interaction across the systems research community. SYSTOR 2025 will be held **virtually on September 8–9, 2025**, in collaboration with the 2nd Israeli Systems & AI Workshop on **September 10, 2025, in Haifa**.

The program includes innovative, peer-reviewed research papers in the broad area of systems and storage, as well as distinguished keynote lecturers, a poster session, and social events. SYSTOR is designed to appeal to academic and industrial researchers and practitioners, welcoming both students and seasoned professionals.

## Topics of Interest

SYSTOR traditionally welcomes academic and industrial papers in systems, including storage, cloud and distributed systems, networking, and systems security, broadly construed. SYSTOR encourages submissions that describe results from experimental system prototypes, as well as experience papers describing practical deployments and valuable lessons learned from them. Topics include, but are not limited to:

*   Systems and workload optimization for AI/ML systems
*   Sustainability/carbon footprint of computer and network systems
*   System security and trust
*   Big Data infrastructure
*   Cloud, edge, data center, and distributed systems
*   Embedded and real-time systems
*   Fault tolerance, reliability, and availability
*   File and storage systems
*   Networked, mobile, wireless, peer-to-peer, and sensor systems
*   Operating systems, computer architecture, and their interactions
*   Performance evaluation and workload characterization
*   Runtime systems and compiler/programming-language support
*   System deployment, usage, and experience
*   System design or adaptation for emerging storage technologies
*   Virtualization and containers
*   Storage 3.0
*   Systems for AI and AI for Systems

## Submission Categories

SYSTOR 2025 solicits submissions in three separate categories:

*   **Full Papers Track:** Original research, at most **12 pages**, excluding references.
*   **Short Papers Track:** Original research, at most **5 pages**, excluding references.
*   **Posters with Extended Abstract Track:** Original work presented as a poster, accompanied by an extended abstract in the conference proceedings.

## Attendance

SYSTOR 2025 will be held virtually on September 8–9. The Israeli Systems & AI Workshop (ISW) will be held physically in Haifa on September 10.

Participation in Systor and the Israeli Systems & AI Workshop is **free**, but **registration is mandatory**.

*   **Register for SYSTOR 2025:** [https://qualtricsxm79nb9h47c.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_d6iX1z4pmLnYYo6](https://qualtricsxm79nb9h47c.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_d6iX1z4pmLnYYo6)
*   **Register for ISW 2025:** [Registration to ISW](https://www.systor.org/2025/isw/)

## Open Access

ACM Systor 2025 is committed to open access, ensuring your work is freely available for download, maximizing its visibility and impact within the research community.

## Important Dates

### Full and Short Papers Track

*   **Paper Submission:** Monday, May 26, 2025 (23:59 AoE)
*   **Acceptance Notification:** Thursday, July 10, 2025
*   **Title and Author confirmation:** Tuesday, July 15, 2025
*   **Camera ready (to shepherd):** Friday, August 1, 2025
*   **Camera ready (post shepherd):** Friday, August 8, 2025

### Posters with Extended Abstract Track

*   **Poster & Abstract Submission:** Thursday, July 10, 2025 (23:59 AoE)
*   **Acceptance Notification:** Thursday, July 17, 2025
*   **Title and Author confirmation:** Tuesday, July 22, 2025
*   **Camera ready (to shepherd):** Friday, August 1, 2025
*   **Camera ready (post shepherd):** Friday, August 8, 2025

### Conference

*   **SYSTOR 2025:** September 8-10, 2025

## Submission Instructions

*   **Research papers (full and short):** Submit through [https://systor25.hotcrp.com/](https://systor25.hotcrp.com/)
*   **Posters:** Submit through [https://systor25posters.hotcrp.com/](https://systor25posters.hotcrp.com/)
*   **ISW-only posters (physical presence required):** Submit by August 15. Send title, abstract, and presenter name to Lior Shafir and Sarel Cohen.

## Review Process

The program committee will review submissions in a **double-blind manner**. All submissions should be properly anonymized, and all identifiable information should be removed whenever possible, including obvious self-references. Papers not properly anonymized may be rejected without review.

Any submissions accompanied by a non-disclosure agreement will be returned without review.

## Copyright and Originality

SYSTOR enforces ACM’s plagiarism policy. Simultaneous submissions are not allowed; any work submitted to SYSTOR must not be under consideration for another workshop, conference, or journal.

## Formatting Instructions

*   Submissions must be printable **PDF files**.
*   Use the **ACM’s acmart Latex class** with the **sigplan proceedings template**.
*   The main LaTeX file structure should adhere to the provided example.
*   Ensure fonts are type 1 (scalable), NOT Type 3 (bit-mapped), and embedded within the document.
*   Include paper keywords (specified with the `\keywords` command).
*   Include a short ABSTRACT section for posters. Do not put your entire extended abstract under this section.
*   Papers/posters must not include page numbers in the final manuscript.
*   Include the ACM copyright text and DOI as provided by ACM.
*   **Submit the source files** for your paper alongside the final PDF.

## Arxiv & Open Source

*   A paper submitted to SYSTOR can be submitted simultaneously to Arxiv, with changes to preserve anonymity. Inform the chairs if an Arxiv version exists.
*   Authors are encouraged to associate an anonymized source code repository with their submission.

## Post Acceptance Instructions

*   Finalize title and author list in HotCRP before the camera-ready deadline.
*   Complete ACM copyright forms to receive copyright text and DOI.
*   Address all reviewer comments for the final version.
*   The shepherd will provide final approval for the camera-ready version.
*   Ensure correct copyright text is inserted and formatting is finalized.
*   Refer to "www.acm.org/publications/gi-proceedings-current" for additional information.

## Organizers

**Program Chairs:** Pramod Bhatotia (TU Munich, Germany), Binoy Ravindran (Virginia Tech, USA)
**General Chairs:** Amit Golander (Tel Aviv University, Israel), Joel Nider (UnifabriX, Israel), Doron Chen (IBM Research, Israel)
**Publication Chair:** Surbhi Palande (University of British Columbia, Canada)
**Poster Chairs:** Lior Shafir (Tel Aviv University, Israel), Sarel Cohen (The Academic College of Tel Aviv-Yaffo, Israel)
**Publicity Chair:** Diana Cohen (Technion, Israel)
**Steering Committee Head:** Dalit Naor (The Academic College of Tel Aviv-Yaffo, Israel)

callForPapers:
# Call for Papers

The 9th IFAC Symposium on System Structure and Control (SSSC 2025), 19th IFAC Workshop on Time Delay Systems (TDS 2025), and 2nd IFAC Workshop on Control of Complex Systems (COSY 2025) will be held jointly in **Gif-sur-Yvette, France**, from **June 30th to July 2nd, 2025**, at **CentraleSupélec** on the Paris-Saclay University campus.

The aim of this joint event is to gather academics and professionals with a particular interest in system structure, control, linear and nonlinear system theory, and to offer them a forum where to discuss current research developments and open problems, as well as to establish scientific networks with a focus on the mathematical structure of systems as well as on the limits it imposes on control systems design and performance.

## Submission Policy

Contributions can be submitted as either an **extended abstract (2 pages)** or a **full paper (minimum 4 and maximum 8 pages initial submission, 6 pages final submission)**, in A4 size and PDF format. Accepted papers will be published in IFAC Papers on-line. Abstract submissions will NOT be published in IFAC Papers on-line but will be included in the conference preprints.

All papers must be submitted through the conference submission website ([https://ifac.papercept.net/conferences/scripts/start.pl](https://ifac.papercept.net/conferences/scripts/start.pl)) formatted in the standard 2-column Proceedings format.

## Important Dates

*   Deadline for invited session: **January 15th, 2025**
*   Deadline for submissions (papers and extended abstracts): **February 10th, 2025**
*   Acceptance notification: **March 27th, 2025**
*   Early registration deadline: **April 14th, 2025**
*   Final submission deadline: **April 30th, 2025**
*   Regular registration deadline: **April 30th, 2025**
*   Late registration deadline: **June 15th, 2025**

## Registration Policy

*   A regular registration by an Author will allow the Author to upload up to 2 accepted papers the Author has (co)authored.
*   A reduced registration for a Student/Retiree Author will allow the Student/Retiree Author to upload up to one of the accepted papers the Student/Retiree Author has (co)authored.

## Publication

Accepted papers that have been presented at an IFAC meeting will be published in the proceedings of the event using the open-access IFAC-PapersOnLine series hosted on ScienceDirect. To this end, the author(s) must grant exclusive publishing rights to IFAC under a Creative Commons license when they submit the final version of the paper.

## Special Calls

*   **Call for Invited Sessions:** Proposals must describe the motivation and relevance of the session.
*   **Call for Tutorial/Panel Sessions:** Tutorials and panel discussions addressing state-of-the-art control theory and advanced industrial applications are solicited.
*   **Call for Workshops:** Workshops to be held prior to the conference are solicited on all related topics.

## Contact

For further information, please refer to: Email: [sssc-tds-cosy-2025@sciencesconf.org](mailto:sssc-tds-cosy-2025@sciencesconf.org)

callForPapers:
# TAP 2024: Call for Papers

TAP 2024 is the **18th International Conference on Tests and Proofs**, promoting research in verification and formal methods. The conference targets the interplay of static and dynamic analysis techniques to improve software and system dependability.

## Invited Speakers

*   **Rosemary Monahan** (Maynooth University, Ireland)
*   **Rüdiger Ehlers** (TU Clausthal, Germany)

## Scope

TAP focuses on the combination of static techniques (such as proving) and dynamic techniques (such as testing). Research in verification increasingly explores heterogeneous techniques and synergy between dynamic and static analysis, recognizing their complementary nature. This includes areas like counterexample generation, integration of SAT/SMT-solving, predicate abstraction, and verification of machine learning systems.

TAP's scope encompasses foundational work, tool development, and empirical research, with a central theme on the combination of static and dynamic analysis techniques.

## Topics of Interest

Papers are solicited on, but not limited to, the following topics:

*   Verification and analysis techniques combining proofs and tests
*   Static analysis of programs with the aid of dynamic techniques
*   Deductive techniques supporting the automated generation of test vectors and oracles
*   Deductive techniques supporting (novel) definitions of coverage criteria
*   Specification inference by deductive or dynamic methods
*   Testing and runtime analysis of formal specifications
*   Search-based techniques for proving and testing
*   Testing and Verification of systems based on machine learning
*   Verification of verification tools and environments
*   Applications of test and proof techniques in new domains
*   Combined approaches of test and proof in the context of formal certifications (Common Criteria, CENELEC, …)
*   Case studies, tool and framework descriptions, and experience reports

## Artifact Evaluation

Authors are encouraged (but not required) to make relevant artifacts available to the reviewers. Artifacts can be provided at submission time or after notification of acceptance and will undergo a lightweight reviewing process, with availability badges awarded.

## Submission and Proceedings

Accepted submissions will be published in **Springer’s LNCS series**.

Please check the [submission page](/2024/submission.html) for detailed instructions for preparing your submission.

## Important Dates

| Event                     | Date                      |
| :------------------------ | :------------------------ |
| Abstract submission (optional) | Extended: **June 12, 2024** |
| Paper submission          | Extended: **June 14, 2024** |
| Paper notification        | July 5, 2024              |
| Artifact submission       | July 7, 2024              |
| Artifact notification     | July 14, 2024             |
| Camera-ready submission   | July 19, 2024             |
| Conference                | **September 9-10, 2024**  |

callForPapers:
# UBICOMM 2025: Call for Papers

The Nineteenth International Conference on Mobile Ubiquitous Computing, Systems, Services and Technologies (UBICOMM 2025) will be held from **September 28, 2025 to October 02, 2025 in Lisbon, Portugal**.

## Onsite and Online Options

To accommodate various situations, the conference offers the option for either physical presence or virtual participation (pdf slides or pre-recorded videos).

## Conference Goals and Scope

The goal of UBICOMM 2025 is to bring together researchers from academia and practitioners from industry to address fundamentals of ubiquitous systems and new applications related to them. The conference provides a forum for presenting recent research results and new research problems. It seeks contributions presenting novel research in all aspects of ubiquitous techniques and technologies applied to advanced mobile applications.

## Conference Tracks

*   **Ubiquity trends and challenges**
*   **Fundamentals**
*   **Mobility**
*   **Slicing and 5/6/7G technologies**
*   **Information Ubiquity**
*   **Ubiquitous Multimedia Systems and Processing**
*   **Wireless Technologies**
*   **Web Services**
*   **Ubiquitous networks**
*   **Ubiquitous devices and operative systems**
*   **Ubiquitous mobile services and protocols**
*   **Ubiquitous software and security**
*   **Collaborative ubiquitous systems**
*   **Users, applications, and business models**

## Special Tracks

*   **EXPLAIN:** Engineering Explainability in Adaptive Intelligent Nexus
*   **ROAM D2DIoT:** Resource Optimization Allocation and Management in Device-to-Device Internet of Things

## Contribution Types

*   **Regular Papers:** (up to 6-10 pages, 6 pages covered by registration, max 4 extra pages at additional cost) (oral presentation)
*   **Short papers (work in progress):** (up to 4 pages long) (oral presentation)
*   **Ideas contributions:** (2 pages long) (oral presentation)
*   **Extended abstracts:** (2 pages long) (oral presentation)
*   **Posters (paper-based):** (2 pages long) (oral presentation)
*   **Posters (slide-based, only):** (oral presentation)
*   **Presentations (slide-based, only):** (oral presentation)
*   **Demos:** (2 pages) [posted on www.iaria.org]
*   **Tutorial proposals**
*   **Panel proposals**

## Submission Instructions

*   Only .pdf or .doc files will be accepted for paper submission.
*   Final author manuscripts will be 8.5" x 11", not exceeding 6 pages; max 4 extra pages allowed at additional cost.
*   Helpful information for paper formatting for MS Word can be found [here](https://www.iaria.org/conferences/UBICOMM25.html).
*   LaTeX templates are available, including the `iaria` CTAN package and an Overleaf template.
*   Submissions should be made via the "Submit a Paper" button on the conference website.
*   Authors of selected papers will be invited to submit extended versions to an IARIA Journal.

## Deadlines

*   **Submission:** Jun 27, 2025
*   **Notification:** Jul 27, 2025
*   **Registration:** Aug 10, 2025
*   **Camera ready:** Aug 24, 2025

Deadlines differ for special tracks. Please consult the conference home page for special tracks Call for Papers (if any).

## Publication

*   Published by IARIA Press (operated by Xpert Publishing Services)
*   Archived in the Open Access IARIA ThinkMind Digital Library
*   Prints available at Curran Associates, Inc.

## Co-located Events

UBICOMM 2025 is co-located with the following events as part of NexTech 2025 Congress:

*   ADVCOMP 2025
*   SEMAPRO 2025
*   AMBIENT 2025
*   EMERGING 2025
*   DATA ANALYTICS 2025
*   GLOBAL HEALTH 2025
*   CYBER 2025
